The great fear of all worlds is as follows: In the thought of permanence, speaking of impermanence; in the thought of happiness, speaking of suffering; in the thought of self, speaking of no-self; in the thought of purity, speaking of impurity; in the thought of existence, speaking of non-existence; in various views, speaking of the thought of emptiness; in the thought of quiescence, speaking of no-thought; in the three realms, speaking of the thought of no-aspiration; in self and what belongs to self, speaking of the thought of non-attachment.
If one is not frightened or terrified by this, then this is called abiding in proper discipline.
Why is it so?
If one gives rise to fear, then one will not be able to uphold this Dharma, namely, clinging to self and what belongs to the self.

Without continuity, there is no heat and distress. Without heat and distress, there are no causes of afflictions. Without the causes of afflictions, one can see the light. Seeing the light, one attains wisdom. Attaining wisdom, one attains a vast mind. Attaining a vast mind, Mara cannot take advantage. Subduing Mara, there are no obstructions. Without obstructions, one can directly attain all Buddha-dharmas.
Thus, Heavenly Son!
Expounding and teaching that all dharmas are unborn and unproduced is called expounding the great supernatural power.
At that time, Shariputra said to Manjushri,
Are all the questions I asked answered by you in secret?
Manjushri said,
Shariputra!

All dharmas are provisionally established by the collection of written words. Written words are inexhaustible, spoken according to one's pleasure. Dharmas have no nature, to be understood as appropriate. Shariputra!
All dharmas are by nature detached, without accumulation, and nothing to be seen, but are expounded in accordance with one's desires.
Moreover, this Dharma does not come from anywhere, nor does it go anywhere, it is neither in the directions nor apart from the directions, without accumulation and without dispersion.
If the Dharma of all buddhas and the Dharma of all sentient beings are expounded with words, they do not come from the body, nor do they come from the mind, but arise from causes and conditions.
Just as those words have no accumulation, the mind and mental factors also have no accumulation.
Just as the mind and mental factors have no accumulation, all afflictions and hindrances also have no accumulation.
Just as the afflictions and hindrances have no accumulation, wisdom also has no accumulation.
Therefore, afflictions and wisdom are both abandoned, because afflictions and wisdom have no abode.
This is called expounding the great spiritual transformation.

The knowledge of cessation, because it demonstrates birth.
The knowledge of the path, because it departs from evil paths.
The knowledge of causes, because what is done is not destroyed.
The knowledge of conditions, because it cuts off birth and death.
The knowledge of the Buddha, because it causes entry into realization.
The knowledge of dependent origination, because it is unattached.
The knowledge of the aggregates, because it eliminates the demon of the aggregates.
The knowledge of the realms, because the realm of phenomena is equal.
The knowledge of the sense bases, because it skillfully observes the empty aggregates.
The knowledge of giving, because it is not untimely.
The knowledge of precepts, because it includes those who violate precepts.

At that time, the god-son Merchant Leader said to MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«, How rare, how rare!
This bodhisattva wisdom is the most supreme in the three realms. It cannot be accomplished with little adornment.
If one can give rise to this wisdom, it is a great spiritual transformation.

If one hears that all sentient beings are originally quiescent and extinguished, and does not give rise to fear, this is called a bodhisattva's complete adornment.
The son of heaven said:
Manjushri!
What is called a bodhisattva?
He replied:
If one practices enlightenment but does not abide in anything, this is called a bodhisattva.
He further asked:
What is called a mahasattva?
He replied:
Having already crossed over all practices and perfected great wisdom, one is a mahasattva.
He further asked:
Why is it called a distinguished being?
He replied:
Because of wisdom, one does not become attached to the Dharma, and because of skillful means, one embraces all. Therefore, it is called a distinguished being.
He further asked:
What is called a pure being?
He replied:
Because they do not dwell with any afflictions and in order to eliminate the afflictions of sentient beings, they give rise to great diligence. This is called the pure sentient beings.
He also asked:
What are called the extremely pure sentient beings?
He replied:
If they cultivate the path in order to liberate all sentient beings, they are called the extremely pure sentient beings.
He also asked:
How are bodhisattvas the guides of the world?
He replied:
If they are able to abide in the path they practice and bring to maturity immeasurable and boundless sentient beings, they are called guides.
He also asked:
How do bodhisattvas abide in self-discipline?
He replied:
If they are able to cause sentient beings who should be disciplined to abide in ultimate self-discipline, this is called self-discipline.
He also asked:
How do bodhisattvas attain courage?
He replied:
If one can mature all sentient beings, crush the demons and enemies, and cause them to escape from birth and death, this is called being courageous.
He also asked:
How is it that bodhisattvas are difficult to discourage?
He replied:
If one can fulfill the vows made in the past and not seek the realization of the paths of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, this is called being difficult to discourage as a bodhisattva.
He also asked:
How is it that bodhisattvas surpass all others?
He replied:
By skillfully protecting and upholding the true Dharma with wisdom, maturing sentient beings, and being looked up to by all gods and humans, this is called surpassing others.
He also asked:
What is it to expound the Dharma?
He replied:
Relying on what the Buddha has said to crush all heterodox theories, this is called expounding the Dharma.
He also asked:
What is it to expound the Vinaya?
He replied:
Abiding in the precepts oneself and being able to sever the afflictions and evil karma of sentient beings is called expounding the Vinaya.
He further asked:
How does one perfect benefiting sentient beings?
He replied:
Turning one's accumulated wholesome roots towards all is called perfecting benefiting sentient beings.
He further asked:
What is upright mind?
He replied:
Not giving rise to aversion towards greedy, hateful, deluded, or deceitful sentient beings.
He further asked:
What is non-deception?
He replied:
Speaking truthfully.
He further asked:
What is being free from deceit?
He replied:
Thinking carefully before speaking.
He further asked:
What is being free from arrogance?
He replied:
Not giving rise to pride towards any sentient being.
He further asked:
What is great giving?
He replied:
The accumulation of unsurpassed enlightenment is difficult to attain, yet you give it to sentient beings, let alone worldly possessions.
He further asked:
What is it to be fully endowed with precepts?
He replied:
Even at the cost of one's life, one should never abandon the bodhi mind.
He further asked:
What is patience?
He replied:
Being able to endure oppression without oppressing others.
He further asked:
What is diligence?
He replied:
Discerning all dharmas, nothing can be obtained.
He further asked:
What is meditation?
He replied:
Not seeing the desire realm.
He further asked:
What is wisdom?
He replied:
Not discriminating anything.
He further asked:
What is it to abide in loving-kindness?
He replied:
Observing the realm of sentient beings as empty and nonexistent.
What is it to abide in compassion?
He replied:
Knowing that all dharmas are empty, yet not abandoning diligence.
How does one abide in joy?
He replied:
Abiding in great tranquil bliss, seeking the Dharma without weariness.
How does one abide in equanimity?
He replied:
Not being tainted by worldly dharmas, yet being able to save the world.
How is the body purified?
He replied:
The body that arises according to one's wishes, equally manifesting to all sentient beings.
How is speech purified?
He replied:
Whatever Dharma is spoken, it never passes in vain, and is able to fully satisfy all sentient beings.
How is the mind purified?
He replied:
The thoughts in the minds of all sentient beings, one is able to understand them all in a single thought.
What is the divine eye?
He replied:
Able to see all forms and appearances, yet without attachment.
What is the divine ear?
He replied:
Hearing all sounds, yet being free from the characteristics of sounds.
What is the knowledge of others' minds?
He replied:
Understanding the arising and ceasing of all minds.
What is the knowledge of past lives?
He replied:
Without moving from the ultimate reality, knowing the past.
What is spiritual power?
He replied:
Without moving from the activities of Mara, destroying all Maras.
What is self-control?
He replied:
Being able to control all that is difficult to control.
What is protection?
He replied:
Not being disturbed by the faculties.
What is being well-disciplined?
He replied:
Not being moved by any phenomena.
What is tranquility?
He replied:
Remaining in the fire of afflictions without being burned, and expounding the Dharma for those who have crossed over afflictions.
What is pure faith?
He replied:
If it is said that the Buddha's body is a dharma of form and appearance, one should not believe or accept it, and not be destroyed by it.
What is a bodhisattva's skillful means?
He replied:
If one sees the afflictions and faults of sentient beings as being equal to enlightenment, this is a bodhisattva's skillful means.

When this teaching was spoken, twelve thousand sentient beings gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, and five hundred bodhisattvas attained acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
At that time the World-Honored One praised him, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Manjushri!
You are well able to expound the practices of bodhisattvas, and have already encompassed all bodhisattvas' immeasurable merits.
At that time the god-son Merchant Leader said to Manjushri:
How many Buddha-World-Honored Ones have you respectfully made offerings to in the past to attain this eloquence?
Manjushri said:
It is like the mind of an illusory person, which has already ceased.
The god said:
The mind-nature of sentient beings is still unobtainable, let alone an illusory person having a mind that has ceased.
He replied:
The nature and characteristics of all Buddhas and Tathagatas are like this. I make offerings to the Tathagatas based on this Dharma.
The god said:
For how long have you been practicing the perfection of generosity?
He replied:
If someone asks a person transformed by the Buddha how long they have been practicing the perfection of generosity, what would be the answer?
The god said:
There is no answer.
Manjushri said:
I am also like this.
Why do you ask how long I have been practicing?
The god said:
Are you abiding in stinginess?
He replied:
Yes, I am.
He asked again:
What do you think?
He replied:
I do not abandon the Buddha's teachings or any sentient beings, and therefore I am stingy.
The god said:
According to what Manjushri has said, is this also breaking the precepts?
He replied:
That is so.
The god said:
What do you think?
He replied:
One who breaks the precepts will fall into an evil realm. In order to liberate suffering sentient beings, I enter the evil realms, and therefore it is called breaking the precepts.
He also asked:
Do you give rise to a mind of harm?
He replied:
That is so.
The god said:
What do you think?
He replied:
A mind of harm is called a mind of non-love.
I have no love at all for afflictions and the two vehicles, and therefore it is called a mind of harm.
He also asked:
Are you lazy?
He replied:
That is so.
He also asked:
What do you think?
He replied:
I do not engage in physical, verbal, or mental actions, do not seek anything, do not grasp or abandon anything, and therefore I am called lazy.
He also asked:
Are you distracted?
He replied:
Yes, I am.
The god said:
What do you think?
He replied:
Is distraction not the state of not dwelling in the mind of liberation?
The god said:
Yes, it is.
He replied:
In order to mature all beings, I do not dwell in liberation, and therefore I am called one with a distracted mind.
He also asked:
Are you without wisdom?
He replied:
Yes, I am.
He also asked:
What do you think?
He replied:
Is being without wisdom the same as being deluded and not fearing birth and death?
The god said:
Yes, it is.
He replied:ğŸ”½Yes, it is.
I am not frightened or afraid in birth and death, but in order to mature foolish and deluded beings, I engage in the same activities as them, and therefore I am called 'ignorant'.
The god said:
Are you one who is worthy of offerings in the world?
He replied:
I give rise to a mind of killing and harming towards all beings.
He was further asked:
What do you think?
He replied:
Because I kill and harm their greed, anger, and delusion, I am one who is worthy of offerings in the world.
The god said:
As you have said, you will cause all worlds to be frightened.
He replied:
God!
If the ultimate truth is frightened, then the world is frightened.
Why is this?
Because the entire world is the ultimate truth.
He was further asked:
If there are people who slander and disparage this teaching, where will they go?
He replied:
They will go to nirvana.
He was further asked:
What is the meaning of this?
He replied:
In the holy liberation there are no written words. Therefore, by destroying verbal expression one can reach nirvana.
For this reason, all dharmas are originally liberated, and do not need to be liberated again.
He further asked:
What is the meaning of this?
He replied:
Those who are already liberated, do they need to be liberated again?
He further asked:
Do those who slander the true Dharma not enter hell?
He replied:
If they are already liberated, they are free from all defilements. How can they go to hell?
The god said:
Manjushri!
As you have said, there is nothing to praise or assist.
He replied:
In emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, what is there to praise or assist?
He further asked:
Where should those who cultivate emptiness dwell?
He replied:
They should dwell in loving-kindness.
Why is it so?
Sentient beings are like illusions, because their intrinsic nature is empty.
The god said:
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«!
How do you understand the realm of sentient beings?
He replied:
Seeing that all sentient beings arise from causes and conditions, neither ceasing nor being permanent, therefore one thoroughly understands the realm of sentient beings.
He further asked:
What is the meaning of the realm of sentient beings?
He replied:
The realm of sentient beings is precisely the dharma realm.
He further asked:
What is the dharma realm?
He replied:
The realm of intrinsic emptiness is called the dharma realm.

He replied:
The realm of space transcends all objects.

He replied:

What is called the realm of the Buddha?
He replied:
The eye realm is the Buddha's realm, but the Buddha's realm is not the realm of the eye, form, or eye consciousness.
The ear realm is the Buddha's realm, but the Buddha's realm is not the realm of the ear, sound, or ear consciousness.
Up to the mind realm is the Buddha's realm, but the Buddha's realm is not the realm of the mind, dharmas, or mind consciousness.
The form realm is the Buddha's realm, but the Buddha's realm is not the realm of form.
The realms of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are the Buddha's realm, but the Buddha's realm is not the realm of feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness.
The realm of ignorance is the Buddha's realm, but the Buddha's realm is not the realm of ignorance.
Up to the realms of old age, sickness, and death are the Buddha's realm, but the Buddha's realm is not the realm of old age, sickness, and death.
The desire realm is the Buddha's realm, because it is characterized by non-greed.
The form realm is the Buddha's realm, because it is not the antidote to greed.
The formless realm is the Buddha's realm, because it is not the view of ignorance.
The unconditioned realm is the Buddha's realm, because it is free from dualistic characteristics.
The conditioned realm is the Buddha's realm, because it is free from the three characteristics.
Celestial son!
This is called the Buddha's realm.
Such a realm enters all realms, whether with or without boundaries, and embraces them all.
Because bodhisattvas skillfully enter this realm, they always practice in all worldly realms, transcending the demonic realm.
Truly understanding the Buddha realm and the demonic realm to be quiescent and equal is called the greatest spiritual transformation.
Furthermore, bodhisattvas do not abide in equality but use the Dharma of equality to mature sentient beings.
What is equality and what is not equality?
Understanding that all dharmas are empty by nature is called abiding in equality.
Being unable to enter the emptiness of the nature of dharmas is called not equality.
Bodhisattvas bring such beings to maturity, yet they do not abide in the equality of emptiness.

All dharmas are equal in being wishless, equal in being unconditioned, equal in being unborn, equal in being unceasing, equal in being free from defilements, equal in being tranquil, equal in being natureless, equal in being extinguished, and equal in being nirvÄá¹‡a.
Those who do not understand this equality of dharmas, bodhisattvas bring such beings to maturity, yet they do not abide in equality.
Therefore, bodhisattvas neither abide in equality nor depart from equality. This is the practice of bodhisattvas.

When this bodhisattva practice was being spoken, five hundred bodhisattvas attained acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.

If one has long accomplished pure karma, then one will be able to cultivate this bodhisattva practice.
At that time, the god-son Merchant Leader said to the Buddha,
World-Honored One!
What is called non-arising?
How can one attain this acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas?
The Buddha said,
Non-arising does not mean that there was arising first and then it is said to be non-arising. It is originally unborn, so it is called non-arising.
It does not mean that there was arising first and then it is said to be non-arising. It is originally non-arising, so it is called non-arising.
It does not mean that there were characteristics first and then it is said to be without characteristics. It is originally without characteristics, so it is called without characteristics.
It does not mean that there was activity first and then it is said to be without activity. It is originally without activity, so it is called without activity.
It does not mean that there were sentient beings first and then it is said to be empty. The nature of sentient beings is empty, so it is said to be empty.
Understanding in this way, there is no arising and no ceasing, and originally nothing to be attached to. This is called non-arising.
What is called patience?
Being patient with all sentient beings and all lands being originally unborn is called patience.
Being patient with all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas being originally unborn is called patience.
Being patient with all bodhisattvas and all buddhas being originally unborn is called patience.
Thus, to be patient with and accept all dharmas as originally unborn is called patience.
Heavenly son!

Because dharmas are unborn, they are empty moment by moment. Because they are empty moment by moment, they are called signless.
